content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mission is responsible for carrying out the good offices of the Secretary-General to enable the resumption of a peaceful, inclusive, orderly and Yemeni-led political transition process that meets the legitimate demands and aspirations of the Yemeni people, including women and youth, for peaceful change and meaningful reform, as set out in the Initiative of the Gulf Cooperation Council and its implementation mechanism and the outcomes of the comprehensive National Dialogue Conference. The mandate derives from Security Council resolution 2014 (2011) and from subsequent Council resolutions, the latest being resolution 2742 (2024).

To ensure the implementation of Security Council resolutions 2014 (2011) and 2051 (2012), together with the political transition agreed in November 2011 under the Initiative of the Gulf Cooperation Council and its implementation mechanism for the political transition process in Yemen, the Secretary-General established the Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on Yemen, in accordance with an exchange of letters with the President of the Security Council in June 2012, which was then subsumed into the Office of the Special Envoy (S/2012/469 and S/2012/470).

In line with Council resolution 2216 (2015), as well as other Council resolutions on Yemen, including resolutions 2014 (2011), 2051 (2012), 2140 (2014), 2201 (2015), 2451 (2018), 2452 (2019), 2722 (2024), 2742 (2024) and the letter from the Secretary-General addressed to the President of the Security Council (S/2016/488), the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen will continue to mediate between the parties to end the conflict. The mission will provide facilitation and technical advice on the negotiation and design of interim political, economic and security arrangements, including towards the resumption of an inclusive, intra-Yemeni political process, under United Nations auspices, and enable the resumption of a peaceful, inclusive, orderly and Yemeni-led political transition process.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to achieve a negotiated political settlement between the parties to end the conflict in Yemen and enable the resumption of a peaceful, inclusive, orderly and Yemeni-led political transition that will lead Yemenis towards a path of sustainable peace.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:
(a)	Utilize negotiations, consultations and shuttle diplomacy to achieve an agreement between the parties to end the conflict in Yemen and resume the political transition;

(b)	Support the Yemen peace process in political and  technical  areas, including in helping the parties identify long-term measures and immediate priorities for political, security and economic issues to resume the political process, implement the Stockholm Agreement and de-escalate the conflict  locally, nationally and regionally;

(c)	Develop a consultative process involving women, civil society and youth, that assesses and integrates their views and recommendations in the mission’s multitrack diplomacy and negotiations on the peace agreement and post-transition process;
(d)	Foster continued regional and international support for resolving the conflict in Yemen;
(e)	Continue to adapt to the evolving political context and operational environment to strengthen mandate implementation.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	A peace agreement, or set of agreements, between the parties on political, economic and military/security measures that will improve the living conditions in Yemen and usher in a sustainable, peaceful and inclusive transitional period;

(b)	Enhanced engagement with diverse Yemeni political and social stakeholders, including women, youth, media entities and the broader public to inform the  United Nations-facilitated political process and strengthen two-way communication;
(c)	Refined security governance options and effective implementation of transitional security arrangements;

(d)	Development of an inclusive transitional agenda informed by women’s and gender perspectives, ensuring these perspectives inform relevant substantive agreements, arrangements, and implementation mechanisms and bodies;
(e)	Continued implementation of the Stockholm Agreement, including the uninterrupted flow of commercial imports into the Hudaydah ports, and further  exchanges of conflict-related detainees.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission also engages closely with international and regional organizations, including the League of Arab States, the Gulf Cooperation Council, the European Union, the International Committee of the Red Cross, and other international partners including international financial institutions.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission cooperates with the Resident/Humanitarian Coordinator and the United Nations country team in Yemen. The mission consults and coordinates closely with the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs and special political missions in the region. In line with Security Council resolution 2452 (2019), the mission closely coordinates with the United Nations Mission to Support the Hudaydah Agreement (UNMHA), which reports to the Secretary-General through the Special Envoy and the Under-Secretary-General for Political and Peacebuilding Affairs, and shares an integrated support structure with UNMHA.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	Despite a complex mediation environment due to regional dynamics, sanction regimes and limitations on staff movement in Houthi-controlled areas, the parties to the conflict will continue to engage in discussions with the Special Envoy, with the aim of reaching a comprehensive political settlement;

(b)	The mission will maintain its presence in Yemen and continue to have access to key Yemeni stakeholders including through digital means, albeit with restrictions imposed by the parties and the security situation on the ground;

The mission integrates a gender perspective in its operations and engages with national and local initiatives that promote women’s political participation and representation, citizenship rights and the incorporation of women’s human rights and security needs in transition, early recovery, conflict resolution and peacebuilding processes.

In line with the UN Disability Inclusion Strategy, the mission will enhance physical access to its office in Yemen, following similar upgrades in Amman in 2024. The mission will also continue its staff awareness-building activities on  disability inclusion.
Programme performance in 2024
Longest period of low level of hostilities since start of conflict continues without a formal truce

The period of relative stability along the Yemeni frontlines continued throughout 2024 due to the United Nations mediated truce, on which Yemenis continue to place much significance. The mission focused on establishing a road map to operationalize and implement commitments agreed upon in December 2023, which included a set of measures to improve the lives of Yemenis, while dialogue and planning continued on de-escalation and a nation-wide ceasefire. Meetings were held with political, economic, and military representatives, as well as media, civil society, women and youth, across multiple governorates in Yemen and in the region to gather their feedback on political, economic and security issues. These activities occurred amidst growing regional and economic tensions, affecting essential financial services. On 23 July 2024, the mission announced that the parties agreed to measures to de-escalate tensions in the banking and air transport sectors. Additional complexities arose from the Houthis’ arbitrary detention of various UN, diplomatic and civil society personnel, leading to a severe restriction on civic space. The mission is working with all stakeholders to secure their immediate and unconditional release.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 40).
Table 40 – Performance measure

table_content.text: The United Nations-mediated truce lasted from 2 April to 2 October 2022, and represented the longest period of calm in the eight-year conflict. The truce contributed to a significant reduction of violence and civilian casualties. It started providing relief to Yemenis as a result of regular commercial flights between Amman and Sana’a and an increase in fuel imports through Hudaydah port

Despite the formal expiry of the 2022 truce, hostilities remained limited. Throughout 2023, flights between Sana’a and Amman continued, and the continued opening of Sana’a airport facilitated the mobility of Yemenis, including for humanitarian and medical reasons. Fuel shipments and deliveries of non-food/non-medicine cargo and construction materials into the ports of Hudaydah also continued after the expiry of the truce

The main provisions of the 2022 truce largely held, despite occasional flare-ups. Hostilities across Yemeni frontlines remained limited and contained. Flights between Sana’a and Amman resumed quickly after a brief halt, with the continued opening of Sana’a airport significantly enhancing the mobility of Yemenis for humanitarian and medical purposes. Fuel shipments and deliveries of essential non-food and construction materials to Hudaydah ports persisted.

children.text: Planned results for 2026 – Result 1: international community mobilized in support of implementing a Yemeni-led, inclusive peace process –  – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission updated the international community on its efforts and interactions with Yemeni interlocutors. Consultations fostered exchanges on supporting a Yemeni-led political process. Intensified track 2 dialogues broadened outreach among Yemeni civil society.

In 2026, the mission will enhance collaboration with the international community to bolster engagement with the parties. Additionally, the mission will continue to engage with international NGOs to support peacebuilding activities.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 41).
Table 41 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Expansion of the mission’s political engagement and consultations to better include diverse Yemeni perspectives and enhance impetus towards a Yemeni-owned and sustainable peace
Mobilization of the international community to identify ways to engage with Yemenis and move towards a sustainable peace process
Increased focus on diverse Yemeni perspectives throughout Yemen and the diaspora through intensified engagement with the international community.

Continued engagement of the international community to ensure consistent support and accompaniment of the Yemeni peace process. Regular consultations with a diverse range of Yemeni stakeholders to ensure the inclusion of their priorities in the peace process
Creation of strategic and inclusive initiatives and fostering of partnerships to transform international support into actionable and sustainable solutions for a Yemeni-led peace process.

children.text: Result 2: expanded political engagement and consultations to better include diverse Yemeni perspectives and enhanced impetus towards a Yemeni-owned and sustainable peace
Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The mission in 2024 exceeded its target of 27 formal consultations with Yemeni interlocutors, with actual 54 consultations conducted. Efforts will focus on broadening inclusion through the mission’s presence in Yemen and Jordan, as well as engaging with engaging  with Yemeni stakeholders both locally and regionally, including through field visits.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson learned is the importance of interdisciplinary approaches to achieve a more inclusive peace process and enhance mediation efforts. In applying the lesson, engagements will address cross-cutting issues and emphasize Yemeni voices including through digital means.

content.text: B.	 Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 43 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 44 – Human resources
a	Comprising one Other level.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the mission amount to $16,657,800 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($11,393,900) for 101 continuing posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 D-2, 1 D-1, 6 P-5, 15 P-4, 10 P-3, 23 Field Service, 13 National Professional Officer, and 1 General Service ( Other level) and 30 Local level posts), including the proposed staff changes below, as well as operational costs ($5,263,900), comprising costs for official travel ($360,200), facilities and infrastructure ($2,946,800), ground transportation ($229,600), air operations ($393,800), communications and information technology ($831,900), medical ($203,300) and other supplies, services and equipment ($298,300).
In 2026, the following changes are proposed for staffing:

Reassignment of a post of Medical Officer (National Professional Officer) in Aden as Associate Engineer in the Engineering and Facilities Management Unit, given the growing operational requirements to manage engineering and facilities management activities in Aden including those currently outsourced to contractors in support of the Chief Engineering Unit based in Hudaydah. The position is needed to maintain facilities,  and ensure uninterrupted power and water supply, manage waste and resolve issues raised by staff;
Conversion of a Procurement Assistant (Field Service) post to a Procurement Assistant (Local level) post in Amman, to improve the structure of the unit and to nationalise and build capacity;

Redeployment of an Information System Assistant (Field Service) post from Amman to Sana’a to ensure uninterrupted information and communication technology (ICT) support in Sana’a as a critical business continuity measure, particularly in situations of unexpected movement restrictions.

Redeployment of a Telecommunication Technician (Field Service) post from Sana’a to Aden to align it with the increased number of staff presence in Aden and ensure required telecommunications technical expertise;

Reassignment of a Security Officer (Field Service) based in Sana’a as Administrative Assistant within the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary General for Yemen in Amman, to meet the growing workload in the Office.

Vacancy rates of 21.1 per cent and 27.9 per cent have been applied to the estimates for international staff and General Service categories, respectively, based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024, and 30.8 per cent has been applied to the estimates for National Professional Officer posts based on actual vacancy rate in March 2025.

The increase in requirements proposed for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025, is attributable to higher requirements for civilian personnel, resulting from the application of latest salary rates, higher common staff costs, and the application of lower vacancy rates of 21.1 per cent and 30.8 per cent, respectively, for international staff and National Professional Officers, compared with the rates of 23.6 per cent and 42.9 per cent, respectively, applied in 2025. The increased requirements are offset in part by the reduced requirements, for : (a) facilities and infrastructure due to application of lower cost-share percentages for the Office of the Special Envoy from 67% to 58% for Sana’a and Aden’s office, parking lot lease and security services; (b) for  ground transportation owing to  the discontinuation of fuel reserve in Aden and Sana’a, and (c) for air operations due to realigning aviation fuel and rental costs of the fixed-wing aircraft in line with the historical flight hour utilization rates.
Extrabudgetary resources
In 2025, an estimated amount of $4 million extrabudgetary resources  will support the Special Envoy’s efforts to reach sustainable, and inclusive agreements to end the conflict in Yemen.
In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the estimated amount of $4 million are projected to support the same activities as in 2025.
